prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PG 1149-110
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: QSO sample: PG1149-110 log MBH = 7.92 -> log M* = 10.34 log Lbol/LEdd = -0.97 -> log SFR = 0.80

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Observations of QSO host galaxies indicate total CO(1-0) luminosities of L'_CO>10^8 K km/s pc^2 (Evans+01,06, Scoville+03). The conversion factor of L'_CO(2-1) to L'_CO(1-0) for QSOs is close to 1 (Carilli&Walter 2013). As described for the comparison sample, we expect ~1/6 of the total luminosity of the inactive galaxies to originate in our region of interest. For the QSO host galaxies, we want to be sensitive to a central gas density a factor twice as high. Thus, we attribute ~1/3 of the total L'_CO to our region of interest, i.e. we aim at detecting CO in the central kpc at a luminosity of ~3*10^7 K km/s pc^2 at a signal-to-noise of 5sigma. This gives a sensitivity of 0.725mJy at z=0.0490.

We tune one BB of Band 6 to the CO(2-1) line (rest frequency = 230.53800 GHz), and the others to the adjacent dust continuum. The default spectral resolution of ~40 km/s will kinematically resolve the ~300 km/s CO line into multiple spectral elements; we will bin them to measure the integrated line flux for our science goal. Additionally, we will use the dust continuum measurements to test the alternative diagnostic to infer the ISM mass from the dust Rayleigh-Jeans tail, recently described by Scoville+ 2014.

We aim at spatially resolving the central region of the QSO host galaxies at a physical resolution of 200 pc. Resolving this size is sufficient to measure and map the gas density within the nuclear neighborhood of interest (Figure 1) and probe for a significant difference in gas density between the QSOs and the comparison galaxies as demonstrated in the SJ. Furthermore, we want to be sensitive within the full crucial central region of 1 kpc radius. Structures on larger scales are not expected to contribute directly to black hole fuelling and do not need to be resolved. At z=0.0490 this size corresponds to a beam size of 0.4 arcsec and a largest angular scale of 2.0 arcsec.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HE 0205-2408
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: QSO sample: HE0205-2408 log MBH = 8.33 -> log M* = 10.69 log Lbol/LEdd = -0.80 -> log SFR = 1.25

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: match to PG1149-110
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: comparison galaxy sample: SDSS J115130.95-000439.9 log M* = 10.41 log SFR = 0.80

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have no CO measurements for our comparison galaxies. However, we can use the COLDGASS survey (Saintonge+2011a) as a reference sample for our galaxies. This survey provides CO(1-0) measurements for SDSS galaxies at lower redshift than we are probing (z<0.05), but covers a large area on the M*-SFR plane. We also matched our QSO survey to the COLDGASS sample in M* and SFR, but not in z. All of the matched galaxies are detected in CO(1-0) with typical luminosities of 10^9 K km/s pc^2. While we don't use the COLDGASS matched sample directly, to avoid systematics by targeting different redshifts for QSOs and controls, we expect our comparison galaxy sample to have similar total CO(1-0) luminosities. As a very conservative estimate, we aim for the same luminosity threshold as our QSO sample, 10^8 K km/s pc^2. Motivated by the simulations and gas density profiles for disk galaxies by Bigiel & Blitz (2012), we expect ~1/6 of the total luminosity of the galaxy sample to originate in our region of interest, i.e ~1.5*10^7 K km/s pc^2 with the central 200pc radius, which we want to detect at a signal-to-noise of 5sigma. This gives a sensitivity of 0.360mJy at z=0.0476

We tune one BB of Band 6 to the CO(2-1) line (rest frequency = 230.53800 GHz), and the others to the adjacent dust continuum. The default spectral resolution of ~40 km/s will kinematically resolve the ~300 km/s CO line into multiple spectral elements; we will bin them to measure the integrated line flux for our science goal. Additionally, we will use the dust continuum measurements to test the alternative diagnostic to infer the ISM mass from the dust Rayleigh-Jeans tail, recently described by Scoville+ 2014.

We aim at spatially resolving the central region of the QSO host galaxies at a physical resolution of 200 pc. Resolving this size is sufficient to measure and map the gas density within the nuclear neighborhood of interest (Figure 1) and probe for a significant difference in gas density between the QSOs and the comparison galaxies as demonstrated in the SJ. Furthermore, we want to be sensitive within the full crucial central region of 1 kpc radius. Structures on larger scales are not expected to contribute directly to black hole fuelling and do not need to be resolved. At z=0.0490 this size corresponds to a beam size of 0.4 arcsec and a largest angular scale of 2.0 arcsec.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will test whether the bulk of supermassive black holes in galaxies grows from gas transported by gravitational instabilites from kpc all the way to the edge of the accretion disk. As a difference to the widely popular but empirically unproven scenario of major galaxy merger-driven inflow of gas, numerical simulations suggest that if for whatever reason the gas density inside the central ~1 kpc is sufficiently high, then a gaseous disk can become gravitationally unstable, forming a cascade of nested, self-propagating instabilities providing efficient gas transport to the very <1pc-center. The clear and testable prediction is a systematically higher mean gas surface density inside the central ~200pc of strongly accreting QSOs, compared to inactive galaxies with otherwise identical mass, SFR, etc. We will test this hypothesis by measuring CO(2-1) inside this region for each five highly accreting QSOs, and z-, mass- and SFR-matched inactive galaxies. The proposed observations, only possible with ALMA, would provide a confirmation of the fuelling hypothesis at >95% significance and answer this decade-old fundamental question on black hole growth.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00842.S, "Are sub-kiloparsec gas densities the decisive parameter for fueling saupermassive black holes?", Andreas Schulze

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo
National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology
